Instituto Federal de Educação Ciência e Tecnologia do Rio de Janeiro Rua Dr José Augusto Pereira dos Santos, nº s/n São Gonçalo RJ CEP 24425-285 Brazil Graphical abstract Phophotungstic acid (HPW) supported on activated carbon (AC) was prepared and used for dehydration of fructose to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), a biomass-derived precursor for chemicals and fuels. Different characterization techniques showed that Keggin structure of HPW was maintained after impregnation process by incipient wetness method with ethanol as solvent. The high mass content of the active phase (50 wt%) on the support resulted in accessible acid sites and high acid density, important for the dehydration reaction. The effects of reaction time, catalyst amount, and temperature were investigated. The catalytic system with dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) as solvent provided an efficient transformation of fructose to HMF, resulting in high HMF yields (99.3 %) and total fructose conversion after 30 min of reaction at 140 °C. Fructose conversion was not significantly affected by the catalyst amount. On the other hand, the increase in temperature resulted in greater and faster conversion. HMF yield was deeply affected by all reaction variables. Moreover, HPW/AC was reused five times without significant loss of activity. Additionally, a kinetic evaluation was performed and the activation energy of fructose conversion to HMF was 109.4 kJmol−1. Keywords 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural Fructose Phosphotungstic acid Activated carbon 1 Introduction In recent decades, studies showed the 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) as a versatile chemical intermediate, with great applicability in biorefineries [1]. HMF has high potential to be converted into a variety of products, such as polymers (e.g. polyethylene furanoate- PEF [2]) and biofuels (e.g. 5-ethoxymethylfurfural – EMF [3]). In this way, HMF is a molecule of great interest to green chemistry and presents itself as a strong candidate to replace non-renewable sources of energy. An example of the green potential of the HMF is the substitution of PET (polyethylene terephthalate), a petrochemical derived polymer, by PEF in plastic bottle manufacturing; it would allow a reduction of GHG (greenhouse gases) emissions from 20 to 35 Mt of CO2 equivalents in a year [4]. In the same way, the use of EMF as a blend for commercial diesel could reduce SO2 emissions and soot [5]. The dehydration of carbohydrates (fructose, glucose, sucrose, inulin, etc.) in acidic medium is extensively explored in scientific literature for HMF production. Special attention is devoted to fructose dehydration. A scheme of the reactions is presented in Fig. 1 . This reaction route generates HMF with high selectivity if compared to other substrates since the furanose form is more reactive than the cyclic structure formed when other carbohydrates are used as substrates. It should be noted that this furanose form is more stable in aprotic solvents, as DMSO (dimethyl sulfoxide) [6,7]. Besides that, the use of DMSO instead of other solvents (protic or aprotic) reduces the number of side reactions, the main obstacle in HMF production. Produced HMF is unstable in acidic medium and parallel reactions could convert HMF, and fructose as well, into soluble and insoluble polymers (humins). Humins have different structures, but an example of these compounds can be seen in Fig. 1. Furthermore, HMF could be rehydrated to levulinic and formic acids, resulting in a decrease of HMF yield. Mushrif et al. [8] demonstrated that HMF preferentially coordinates with DMSO, offering a shield and preventing its rehydration to organic acids. The search for highly active catalysts and optimum reaction conditions is considered essential to obtain high yields of HMF, aiming at future industrial application. Over the years, several researches have shown the influence of reaction conditions and composition on HMF production, as well as how catalytic properties can improve its synthesis. Takeuchi et al. [11] reported that moderate mineral acids (e. g. H3PO4) are more selective for HMF synthesis, since strong mineral acids favor furan ring activation, which increases levulinic acid yield. The use of homogeneous catalysts (e.g. mineral acids) does not allow catalyst recovering from the reaction media. This is an economic and environmental issue, once catalyst cannot be reused and this acid requires an extra neutralization step. Several heterogeneous catalysts were also evaluated and cited in the literature, such as silica (Cr-K10 clay [12], Al-SBA-15 [13], Fe3O4-SBA-SO3H [14]), carbon-based catalysts [15], oxides (TiO2 [16], SO4 2−/ZrO2 [17], Nb2O5 [18]), phosphates [19] and zeolites [20] (H-ZSM-5 [21], H-mordenite [22], H-Beta [23]). These studies showed that temperatures between 110 and 140 °C favor the HMF synthesis. Temperatures above this range reduce the HMF yield and favor side reactions. On the other hand, these studies reported that reaction times longer than 1 h are necessary to high HMF yield (>90 %). According to this scenario, the design of an efficient acid catalyst is a key point for HMF synthesis with high yields. For this goal, it is interesting to obtain a catalyst that provides rapid dehydration of the substrate in HMF but does not provide HMF rehydration. Keggin type heterepolyacids (HPAs) are strong acid compounds, consisting of a central cation (heteroatoms: P, As, Si, Ge, B, etc.) surrounded by polyanions [9]. Their characteristics are attractive for catalytic application converting biomass into HMF and its derivatives. HPAs are considered a promising option for different furan derivatives synthesis mainly because the presence of strong Brønsted acid sites. However, HPAs present low thermal stability and their separation from the reaction media is hampered by their high solubility in polar solvents [24–26]. In this way, using HPAs in their supported form is an alternative to circumventing these drawbacks. Literature presents phosphotungstic heterepolyacids (HPW) and their salts are a great choice for the conversion of sugars. Zhao et al. [27] reported high selectivity to HMF (94 %) after 60 min at 115 °C using Cs2.5H0.5PW12 as catalyst in water:MIBK (methyl isobutyl ketone) biphasic system. Authors also claimed this catalyst is tolerant to high concentrations of raw material (50 wt.% fructose). In a previous work of our group [9], the activity of HPW and Cs-exchanged phosphotungstic acid (HCsPW) in HMF synthesis, as well as HPW supported on MCM-41, was evaluated, using DMSO as solvent. The use of HCsPW as catalyst resulted in a reduction in HMF yield if compared to the reaction with HPW, which was caused by the lower acidity of HCsPW. HPW supported in MCM-41 showed 100 % of fructose conversion and 80 % of HMF yield after 60 min at 120 °C. Song et al. [28] studied several types of salts of phosphotungstic acid (K, Zn, Ni, Cs, Cu, and Ce) for dehydration of fructose to HMF in different solvents (DMSO, MIBK, n-butanol, sec-butanol)under N2.In this study, authors reported that protic solvents performed better than aprotic solvents and CePW12O40 showed the highest catalytic activity. However, they did not perform any catalyst acidity characterization and not explore the very similar results obtained with DMSO and sec-butanol. The optimal 5-HMF yield was 99.4 % at 158 °C, after 164 min of reaction time in the presence of CePW12O40. In a more detailed work, Lv et al. [29] studied the dehydration of fructose in aqueous and biphasic system over silica-included HPW and HSiW (tungstosilicic acid) as catalysts. In aqueous system, higher fructose conversion was achieved over HPW/SiO2 than HSiW/SiO2, regardless of the reaction temperature (140–180 °C), but higher HMF yield was obtained using HSiW/SiO2 at 170 °C (50.2 %). According to the authors, HMF is more stable under HSiW/SiO2, once the acid strength of HPW is greater than HSiW. Besides that, the experiments showed a suppression of HMF degradation with the increase of MIBK content, improving HMF selectivity in reaction, and eliminating humin formation and deposition on the catalyst surface. The best condition for HMF synthesis was: 180 mg of fructose, 5 mL solvent (VMIBK/ Vwater = 3), 170 °C, 160 min, 18 mg of HSiW/SiO2, 0.25 mmol of fructose, with fructose conversion and HMF yield of 90 and 82 %, respectively. Huang et al. [30] successfully described the preparation of HMF from glucose in the presence of HPW/SiO2 with 78.31 % yield of HMF at 160 °C for 140 min and acetone/water mixture as solvent. Nonetheless, the HMF yield decreased about 10 % when the HPW/SiO2 was reused the fifth time. In our previous work, the use of HPW for HMF synthesis has shown promising results with 92 % of HMF yield after 30 min at 120 °C in DMSO [9]. Recently, Nogueira et al. [31] also reported that HPW supported in Nb2O5 was a promising catalyst for HMF production. Furthermore, when evaluating the type of supports (Nb2O5 or Al2O3) and the conditions used for preparing the HPW catalysts, the authors concluded that the presence of Lewis and Brönsted acid sites strongly affects the catalyst performance. After optimizing reaction conditions, 40.8 % of HMF yield was reported using glucose as a substrate at 160 °C in water-acetone (1:1 v/v) mixture as solvent and 30 min reaction time. These results suggest that HPW is a good candidate for the development of an efficient catalytic process to produce HMF. However, further investigations of the use of HPW in its supported form is necessary to improve its activity and reusability [9,27,32,33] Activated carbons (AC) are widely used in catalysis, especially as support, mainly due to their textural properties, such as high specific area and high porosity. Moreover, AC structure is composed of functional groups on the surface that act as an anchor point for active phases in the preparation of supported catalysts [32]. Almohalla et al. [33] and Zhang et al. [34] reported that supporting HPAs in porous carbon materials is an excellent choice for heterogenous catalysts, because these solids exhibiting excellent stability and reusability in water or organic solvents. Thus, according to the exposed, an exploratory research was performed to evaluate the potential of AC as support for HPW, envisioning a heterogeneous and highly active catalyst for fructose dehydration to HMF. Reactions varying time, catalyst amount and temperature were performed and their influence on fructose conversion and HMF yield was evaluated. Additionally, catalyst characterization was performed to better understand how catalyst properties affect fructose dehydration. Catalyst reusability was investigated, a kinetic model was also proposed and the activation energy for the system was determined. 2 Experimental D-fructose, Keggin-type 12-tungstophosphoric acid (HPW) and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Corporation. Carbon (LA 810) was purchased from Alphacarbo Industrial Ltda. All reagents were used as supplied without further purification. 2.1 Catalyst preparation First of all, 12-tungstophosphoric acid was calcined in air (30 mL min−1) for 3 h at 350 °C to be tested as catalyst in the reactions without being supported. Activated carbon was pre-treated according to Chimienti et al. [35] to eliminate the soluble acidic and alkaline impurities. This pretreatment consisted on washing activated carbon (AC) in a solution of 0.1 mol L−1 NaOH, followed by a second washing process in a solution of 0.1 mol L-1HCl; each washing was carried out for 30 min at room temperature. In a second step, activated carbon was treated with a solution of HNO3(30 % w/v) and heated up to boiling point in a reflux system for 2 h. Finally, the slurry was filtered and washed with deionized water till pH∼7 and solid AC was dried at 60 °C for 16 h. 12-tungstophosphoric acid on activated carbon (HPW/AC) was prepared by incipient wetness method [24]. Typically, 1.5 g of HPW was dissolved in 90 mL of ethanol, then 1.5 g of activated carbon was added into the HPW solution; it corresponds to 50 wt% of HPW in the catalyst. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 12 h, and the ethanol was evaporated under reduced pressure. The resulting solid was dried at 120 °C overnight and then calcined in air (30 mL min−1) for 3 h at 350 °C. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Acid properties of the support and catalysts were determined by acid-base titration for the quantification of the total number of acid sites and temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) profiles to identify the acidic strength of active sites. In a typical procedure of titration, catalyst (500 mg) was dispersed in 50 mL of 0.2 mol L−1 NaCl aqueous solution. The dispersion was stirred for 24 h and titrated with 0.01 mol L−1NaOH in the presence of phenolphthalein [35]. For TPD-NH3, ammonia adsorption was carried out at room temperature with 4 % NH3/He (30 mL min−1) for 30 min, followed by purging with He for 1 h. The desorption of chemisorbed ammonia was performed by heating up to 700 °C at 10 °C min−1 under He flow (30 mL min−1). The desorbed NH3 was detected using a mass spectrometer Pfeiffer Vacuum Prisma Plus. Thermogravimetric (TGA) and differential thermal (DTA) analyses were performed using a TA Instrument SDT-Q600. The experiments were carried out from room temperature up to 700 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under nitrogen flow (50 mL min−1). N2 absorption-desorption experiment was carried out at −196 °C using ASAP 2020 equipment (Micromeritics). The samples were outgassed for 24 h at 300 °C. The specific surface area was obtained by using the Brauner-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and pore volume and mean pore diameter by Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Morphology of the samples was investigated by means of scanning electron microscope Hitachi TM-3000 and the chemical composition of HPW and HPW/AC was determined by energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDS) of W, P, C and O elements. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) measurements were recorded in KBr discs on a Shimadzu PRESTIGE-21 spectrometer with the wavenumber range of 400−4000 cm−1. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were determined with a Rigaku Miniflex II diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator and CuK α radiation (30 kV and 15 mA). The pattern was scanned in the 2θ rage 2.5−90°. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed in a surface analysis chamber equipped with a VG Thermo Alpha 110 hemispherical analyzer with an x-ray source of Al-Kα. The possible surface charge effect (shift in electron energy) was observed using the C1 s (C–C) photoemission line (284.6 eV). The XPS data were analyzed using the CASA XPS software, assuming Voigt line shapes and Shirley background. 2.3 Catalytic tests All fructose dehydration reactions were carried out in 50 mL glass reactor equipped with a reflux condenser. This system was heated with a thermostatically controlled oil bath. In a typical procedure, fructose (500 mg - 2.77 mmol) was dissolved in DMSO (20 mL) and then the catalyst (100 mg) was added into the fructose solution, which corresponded to 10 wt% of the active phase in the fructose solution. The resulting mixture was charged into a reactor and it was placed in the oil bath at 120 °C. The samples were collected from 0 to 120 min. Different reaction conditions were tested, as temperature (100 and 140 °C) and active phase concentration (5 and 15 % w/w). After each fructose dehydration reaction, the catalyst was filtered and all products were analyzed by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) in a Shimadzu Prominence system, equipped with diode-array (DAD) and refractive index (RID) detectors. An Aminex HPX-87H column (Biorad) was used, with 0.01 mol L−1 H2SO4 as the mobile phase at a flow rate of 1.0 mL min−1 for 40 min. The column temperature was maintained at 40 °C. The calibration curves for fructose and HMF are presented in Supplementary Material (Figs. S1 and S2). The fructose conversion (Cf) and the HMF yield (YHMF) are described in Eqs. 1 and 2, respectively. (1) X f % = moles offructose reacted moles of fructose initial ×100 (2) Y HMF ( % ) = moles of HMF produced moles of fructose initial ×100 2.4 Recycling of catalyst The stability of the HPW/AC catalyst was evaluated through five recycling tests. After each reaction, the catalyst was recovered from reaction system by filtration, washed with deionized water and dried at 120 °C overnight; after drying it was calcined in air (30 mL min−1) for 3 h at 350 °C. After five cycles, this solid was characterized by EDS and XPS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Table 1 shows the chemical composition and the quantification of acid sites by titration, of AC, pure HPW and HPW/AC. The molar ratio between tungsten and phosphorus of the pure phosphotungstic acid, measured by EDS, was 12.8 and it is consistent with the theorical value that is 12. The mass percentage between HPW/AC (51 % HPW and 49 % AC), measured by EDS, is in agreement with the theoretical value indicating that impregnation methodology was efficient. NH3-TPD profiles of the catalysts are displayed in Fig. 2 and were used to understand the strength of the acid sites. The total amount of acid sites is provided in Table 1 and was measured by titration as previously mentioned. Using this method, the interaction of the acidic sites of the catalyst in the liquid phase can be measured more accurately, which does not occur in traditional methods of characterizing acidity in the gas phase [36]. In this way, ammonia desorption was used only to investigate the acid strength of the catalyst. According to the literature, the temperature of ammonia desorption peaks is used to classify the acid sites according to the strength. They are classified into three types: weak (150–300 °C), medium (300–500 °C) and strong (500–650 °C) strength [37,38]. Activated carbon showed the lowest acidity (0.04 mmolH+.gcat −1), as expected. Ammonia desorption peaks from AC were observed at lower temperatures (150−300 °C), characteristic of weak acid sites. This acidity is associated with the presence of acid functional groups on the support surface, such as carboxyl, hydroxyl, and carbonyl groups [39]. HPW presented much higher total acidity by titration (3.67 mmolH+.gcat −1) if compared to the other solids; its NH3-TPD profile shows three peaks appearing at approximately 190, 380 and 630 °C. According to NH3 desorption temperature and the different location and coordination of NH3 in the HPW crystal lattice, the first peak is related to weak acid sites and can be associated with desorption of hydrogen-bonded NH3 molecules; the second peak is associated with moderate acidity sites and are related to decomposition of bonded NH4+ in contact with oxygen atom of single Keggin unit; the third peak (and also the more intense) is related to strong acid sites, which are associated with decomposition of bonded NH4+ in contact with oxygen atom located between two Keggin units [40–44]. As expected, the total amount of acid sites decreased when HPW is anchored on the support, if compared to the total acidity of the pure HPW. However, HPW/AC showed significant acidity (0.89 mmolH+.gcat -1). These results agree with those published by Kozhevnikov et al. [43], who also observed that the acid strength of HPW was greatly reduced when loading on activated carbon. The interaction of HPW with OH groups present on AC surface can be associated with the formation of isolated Keggin anions and, consequently, with the acidity of the HPW/AC catalyst [34]. This is corroborated by NH3-TPD profile of HPW/AC that presents no peak at 630 °C; instead of it, a wide peak between 170 and 430 °C is observed. These results show that the loading of HPW into the support successfully introduced a great number of medium-strength acid sites on the surface of the catalyst. As previously mentioned, ethanol was used as solvent for the solubilization of HPW and its impregnation on AC. This approach provided higher availability of acid sites due to high HPA contents, since a multilayer coverage of HPW on the support was avoided and, consequently, depolymerization of Keggin structure did not take place [45–47]. The stability of HPW, AC and HPW/AC, before calcination, was evaluated by TG/DTA measurements, under N2 atmosphere, as displayed in Fig. 3 . The profile obtained for AC exhibits a weight loss up to 100 °C, corresponding to the loss of water molecules adsorbed on the surface of the material, followed by a continuous weight loss from 450 to 600 °C, associated with thermal decomposition of the organic carbon structure [46]. The AC presented 8.9 % ash and this result is consistent with the literature for chemical activation [47]. The DTA curve (Fig. 3B) showed a small endothermic peak at 65 °C due to dehydration of material and an exothermic peak at 577 °C associated with the oxidation process [48]. Typical TG patterns for the Keggin-type heteropolyacids were presented by pure phosphotungstic acid (H3PW12O40.nH2O). The major weight loss occurred before 100 °C, related to the elimination of water molecules, which are followed by an endothermic peak at 73 °C in the DTA curve (Fig. 3B). These water molecules are responsible for the crystallization of heteropolyanions into a hydrate. The second weight loss for HPW occurred from 150 to 250 °C and corresponds to the loss of constitutional water. This loss is followed by another endothermic peak at 194 °C in the DTA curve (Fig. 3B). A plateau, between 250 and 400 °C, can be described as the formation of anhydrous acid (H3PW12O40). Ultimately, the third weight loss is described as heteropolyanion decomposition (Keggin structure decomposition), with the crystallization of oxides, resultingP2O5and WO3. The presence of an exothermic peak at 604 °C in the DTA curve is caused by the release of energy from this reaction. Similar TG and DTA profiles are reported in the literature [25,35,49]. TG profile for HPW/AC presents a small weight loss up to 100 °C due to the dehydration process. HPW/AC is thermally stable at temperature up to 400 °C, when the catalyst mass starts to decrease, as reported by Carminati et al. [50]. After that, HPW/AC shows a mass loss of 50 %, which corresponds to total thermal decomposition of support from 420 to 615 °C and the rate of degradation become stable at higher temperatures. The thermal decomposition of carbon structure for HPW supported on AC was also observed by Holclajtner-Antunović et al. [51] from 450 to 650 °C.DTA curves of pure HPW and HPW/AC show a plateau between 180 and 400 °C, which can be associated with the higher stability of HPW supported on activated carbon. On the other hand, DTA curves of HPW/AC and pure AC showed a displacement from the exothermic peak to lower temperatures (508 °C)when HPW is supported, as also reported byHolclajtner-Antunović et al. [51]. Since HPW has a high number of oxygen atoms, it can act as a powerful oxidant agent, favoring activated carbon burning by decreasing its oxidation temperature. These results show that the catalyst is stable and can be used at temperatures as high as 450 °C. Obali et al. [52] also indicated similar results for 25 wt.% HPW supported on activated carbon. The textural properties of the catalysts were obtained by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. 4 ). The BET specific surface area and pore volume of all samples are depicted in Table 1. AC and HPW/AC presented a type IV isotherm, typical of mesoporous materials, but also display features of type II, typical of macroporous materials. The hysteresis loops are different for the two evaluated solids. Pure AC gives rise to H3 hysteresis, which is associated to slit-shaped pores, while the hysteresis loop presented by HPW/AC is H4 that is often associated with narrow slit pores [53]. The decrease in the BET specific surface area and pore volume of the supported catalyst (HPW/AC) was significant, 67 % and 85 %, respectively, when compared to AC. These drop in specific surface area and pore volume is consistent with the literature and suggests that the HPW is deposited inside the mesoporous and it is well dispersed on the AC surface [54,55]. Comparing these results with other works in the literature that present HPW supported on different porous solids and using different impregnating solutions, such as HPW/MCM-41 (SBET = 114 m2. g−1)- methanol: water [9], andHPW/NbP (SBET = 60 m2. g−1)– water [40], it can be observed that the use of AC as support and ethanol:water as solvent in the catalyst preparation allowed the HPW deposition without depolymerization, keeping the surface area high [44]. This result presents AC as a promising porous support for anchoring high mass content of HPW catalyst. The Keggin-anion density on the catalyst (HPA nm−2) was calculated as described by Chai et al. [56] and it is related to HPW loading and the surface area of the sample (Table 2 ). It corresponds to the number of Keggin anions per square nanometer. According to the literature, HPW/AC showed a small reduction on Keggin-anion density if compared to theoretical monolayer coverage (0.6 HPWnm-2), which indicates a good dispersion of HPW over the AC and low HPW decomposition. Carminati et al. [50] also presented analogous results when a large amount of HPW was supported on activated carbon. Authors reported a 75 % loss in specific surface area, which is 10 % higher if compared to our results. This difference may be linked to the use of only water to solubilize the HPW (impregnating solution), which favors the HPW depolymerization and reduces the specific surface area. In a previous work [9], the HPW anchorage on MCM-41 also reduced the pore volume from ≥0.70 to 0.08 cm3 g−1, due to the partial blockage of the support pores; this same behavior was also observed for HPW/AC (Table 2). SEM images of the catalysts are presented in Fig. 5 . The micrographs show a great similarity between the particle size of HPW/AC and support. In addition, the EDS mapping of elements (C, O, W, and P) is depicted in Fig. 6 – each colored dot represents an atom or a cluster of atoms referring to the analyzed element. Both analyses indicate that HPW/AC is well dispersed as homogeneous particles in comparison with pure AC. Fig. 7 shows the FTIR spectra of the catalysts. The four major FITR bands characteristics of the Keggin structure can be clearly seen for pure HPW: 1060–1080, 960–980, 880−860, 740−790 cm−1, attributed to υas (POa), υas (WOt), υas (WOb W) and υas (WOc W) vibrations, respectively. These bands are related to different types of oxygen in the Keggin structure: the oxygen of the central tetrahedral PO4 (Oa), the terminal oxygen connected to tungsten atom alone (Ot), the bridge oxygen amid two different W3O13 groups (Ob) and the bridge oxygen in the same W3O13 group (Oc) [57–61]. For AC, the FTIR spectrum provides information on its chemical structure (CC, CO, OH bonds and so on). The band at 3455 cm−1 refers to υ(OH) of the hydroxyl, carboxyl and phenolic groups. Bands in the region between 2760 and 2400 cm−1 are ascribed to υ(CH). The band at 1634 cm−1 is attributed to υ(CC) vibrations in conjugated olefinic CC bonds. The band at 1383 cm-1 may indicate the presence of methyl groups (δs(CH3)). The presence of υ(C–H)can be attributed to the existence of a band at 830 cm-1 [62,63]. FTIR spectrum of HPW/AC indicates that the Keggin structure is preserved, even with the presence of acidic groups from the support. The characteristic bands of the HPW and AC appear slightly shifted in the catalyst (HPW/AC), meaning that Keggin units remained preserved after HPW was anchored on the support. This shift was noticed due to the new interactions that occurred between HPW and AC. It is possible to observe that bands related to Keggin structure are less intense in the HPW/AC catalyst. It is due to HPA loading in AC. Similar results were also observed by Pizzio et al. [44], Chimienti et al. [35] and Badday et al. [62]. Pizzio et al [44]. reported that low amount of supported HPW does not allow the characteristic bands of the acid to be detected by FTIR. It should be noted that the spectra of HPW/AC do not show any bands characteristic fυ(POC) stretching at ∼1160 cm−1 [75], which allows ruling out the existence of direct CP. This is another guarantee that the Keggin structure is maintained after anchoring on AC. Moreover, the reduction in methyl groups (δs(CH3) - 1385 cm−1) and the increase in bands in the 1600 cm−1 regions (assigned to υ(CO) stretching of carboxylic acids, anhydrides, lactones, esters and quinones) and 3400 cm−1(assigned to υ(OH)) indicate that the HPW anchorage promoted the oxidation of the carbon surface, increasing the amount of oxygenated groups. These characteristic bands demonstrate that there were smooth changes in the surface AC, caused by the contact with HPW. Fuerstenau et al. [63] reported that the surface charge on coal is controlled by the dissociation/ionization of oxygenated functional groups on its structure and it is directly related to the pH of the solution in which the coal was immersed. Thus, it can be concluded that the contact between AC and HPW solution resulted in the modification of some surface characteristics of the support. X-ray diffraction patterns of the pure phosphotungstic acid, activated carbon and HPW/AC are presented in Fig. 8 . For pure HPW, the main XRD lines are at 2θ = 10.5°, 18.3°, 23.7°, 26.1°, 30.2°, 35.6°, and 38.8°, which are normally attributed to the cubic structure of the Keggin-type heteropolyacids and are in agreement with the literature (JCPDS - #7521-25) [64]. On the other hand, there are no diffraction peaks assigned to AC, characteristic of amorphous materials, and a small peak at 2θ = 26.4° attributed to graphitic carbon [65]. XRD pattern of HPW/AC (Fig. 8) shows diffraction peaks assigned to HPW, with less intensity. Based on the high HPW loading on support, it may suggest that HPW is well dispersed on the AC surface. In this way, HPW is on the AC surface as very small crystallites, as described in the literature by Chen et al. [61] and Juan et al. [66]. It is a strong indication that catalyst synthesis by incipient wetness method using ethanol as solvent is better for high heteropolyacid dispersion on support than the use of methanol or water as solvents. Aqueous impregnation can promote support hydrolysis for high loadings of HPW. Furthermore, high Keggin-anion density can be observed with water as well [42]. The XPS spectra of the activated carbon (Fig. S3 A–D) are typical of amorphous and aromatic carbon due to the presence of a symmetric peak centered at 284.6 in C1 s spectrum, corresponding to CC bond. Another four peaks were observed in this spectrum: COC (286.1 eV), CO (287.5 eV) and OCO (289.0 eV) and π-π* (291.0 eV). These peaks correspond to different species on the surface of AC, like alcohols, phenols, ester, keto groups and carboxyl groups [67]. A small amount of P was also detected on the surface of the activated carbon. The possible structure of the phosphorus species is proposed to be phosphates (133.5 and 134.4 eV) [68] and P4O10 species (136.4 and 137.2 eV), each specie undergoes the effect of spin-orbit splitting (P 2p3/2 and P 2p1/2). O1 s spectrum of the AC was fitted to single bonded oxygen in COH, COC and/or COP linkages (532.7 eV) [69]. In Fig. S4, XPS spectra of the pure HPW (after its calcination at 350 °C) are presented. XPS O1 s spectrum (Fig. S4 A) shows a peak assigned to single bonded oxygen species [70]. In Fig. S4 B, XPS spectrum of the W 4f region shows two peaks in 35.9 eV and 38.1 eV (the spin-orbit splitting of ∼2.17 eV), associated with W 4f5/2 and W 4f7/2, respectively, assigned to W6+ [71]. P 2p peak in a well crystallized structure consists of a doublet with 0.84 eV of separation due to the spin-orbit splitting [70]. A single peak in 134.2 eV with a doublet (P 2p3/2 in 134.1 eV and P 2p1/2 in 135.0 eV) with 0.9 eV of separation was observed in Fig. S4 C. HPW/AC XPS spectra are presented in Fig. 9 A–E. P 2p spectrum presented a single peak in 134.2 eV with doublets of P 2p3/2 in 133.8 eV and P 2p1/2 in 134.7 eV, meaning the crystallized structure is maintained after impregnation. W 4f spectrum shows that after HPW impregnation, the peaks positions were 35.6 eV (W 4f7/2) and 37.8 eV (W 4f5/2) These peaks shifted (∼300 meV) to lower binding energies indicate more electron transfer from HPW to AC, meaning a more intimate interaction between HPW and AC support [71].These binding energy levels are in accordance with those of P and W in a Keggin anion [70]. Analyzing the O1 s XPS spectra, it is observed that after incorporation of HPW into AC, the O1 s peak migrated into the negative direction. AC showed one peak centered at 532.7 eV (attributed to COH); after incorporation of the Keggin unit, one peak centered at 531.3 eV was detected, indicating that −OH groups were replaced by COW bonds. This observation agrees with the literature [72], which describes the HPW as electron donor assisting in the formation of new bonds between the acid and the support. 3.2 Catalytic tests of fructose dehydration Dehydration experiments were carried out to investigate the catalytic performance of HPW supported on activated carbon (HPW/AC) when compared to HPW and AC separately; these results are shown in Fig. 10 . The use of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) as an aprotic solvent was based on the previous work [9] since it is a great sugar dissolving solvent compared to ethanol and acetone, for example. In addition, furanose conformation of fructose is predominant in DMSO, which favors the formation of HMF, once this conformation is more reactive than other fructose structures [6,7,73]. In addition, DMSO has a preferential coordination around HMF than water, providing a shielding effect [8] and suppressing unwanted side reactions, such as fructose polymerization and hydration to organic acids. It should be noted that the fructose dehydration occurs without the presence of catalyst (blank test), as well as the HMF production. All fructose is converted after 40 min and 81 % of HMF yield is obtained in 80 min of reaction at 120 °C. Zhao et al. [74] presented a similar result in their blank test, with fructose conversion of 56 % and HMF selectivity of 22 % in 30 min at 140 °C. Amarasekara et al. [75], studying the mechanism of the dehydration of d-fructose into HMF using NMR, reported the DMSO acts as the catalyst at 150 °C. After 12 min it was already possible to observe the formation of HMF. These authors reported that this carbohydrate is preferably in furanose form (α-furanose and β-furanose) when soluble in DMSO at different temperatures. This anomeric form of d-fructose is more selective for producing HMF. In addition, literature reports that heating DMSO (> 80 °C) in the presence of oxygen causes its degradation into acidic compounds, such as sulfuric acid [76]. The presence of this acid catalyzes fructose dehydration reaction, since there are no reports of similar results for other solvents (water, water:MIBK), at the same temperature and time [7,6,27,70]. Furthermore, Mushrif et al. [8] suggested that there is a strong bond between fructose and DMSO, and this bond shields fructose of side reactions, without impairing the initialization of the HMF synthesis. When fructose dehydration was performed using AC as catalyst, it took 60 min to achieve 100 % of fructose conversion, followed by 60 % of HMF yield. AC surface consists of the oxygen-containing functional groups such as OH and COOH [77]. These functional groups are capable of adsorbing fructose forming hydrogen bonds with its free hydroxyl groups; it is responsible for the high affinity between substrate and support. Nishimura et al. [78] investigated fructose adsorption on activated carbons and concluded that there is a strong affinity of these solids and fructose. Authors also observed the low conversion of fructose and yield to HMF, even at 155 °C and 1 h in aqueous solution. In this way, this affinity could be delaying fructose conversion by the action of acidic species derived from DMSO. The same behavior was observed in our previous work [9], when the conversion and yield obtained with MCM-41 were lower than those of the blank test (just DMSO), despite the presence of acid sites in its surface. On the other hand, AC contained a certain amount of weak acidic sites (oxygen-containing groups) that contribute to capability for catalyzing the dehydration of fructose. Although it is not possible to be sure which factors govern the conversion of fructose in the presence of pure AC, this solid is not promising for the production of HMF. The literature reports the need for changes in its surface so that it can be used as a catalyst for the dehydration of carbohydrates [70,75]. Therefore, there is a need to use AC only as a support for anchoring the HPW and, thus, enabling the recovery of the catalyst. The initial reaction rates of HMF formation were calculated based on curves of HMF concentration vs. time. The obtained values were 0.34 and 0.16 mol h−1 g−1 for HPW and HPW/AC. The initial rate of anchored of HPW is lower than the one obtained for pure HPW, which was expected since HPW is soluble in the reaction media, favoring the interaction between the substrate and catalyst. Moreover, it presents higher acidity if compared to HPW/AC and fructose showed high affinity with support, which may favor the decrease in initial rates of HMF formation when HPW/AC is used as catalyst. In our previous work [9], using HPW/MCM-41 as catalyst, the initial rate of HMF formation was 0.22 mol.h−1. g−1 under the same reaction conditions. The higher initial rate of HMF formation presented by HPW/MCM-41 when compared to HPW/AC can be explained by its higher acidity. It is worth mentioning that, for long reaction times, this lower acidity of HPW/AC is interesting, since it reduces parallel reactions that consume HMF. To clarify, using HPW/MCM-41 HMF yield was less than 80 % in 120 min of reaction, while it was 90 % using HPW/AC. These results show that the evaluated catalytic system may be considered as an option to promote fructose dehydration to HMF in heterogeneous medium. This conclusion is mainly due to its high reaction rate when compared to other catalysts reported in the literature. Moreau et al. [32] reported reaction rates around 0.03 mol h−1 g−1 for fructose dehydration using H-MOR as catalyst, in MIBK/water solvent, at 165 °C. According to the results of fructose conversion and HMF yield, pure HPW is able to convert all the fructose present in the reaction media in 10 min with 80 % of HMF yield, while HPW/AC took almost 20 min to convert 100 % of fructose, reaching similar HMF yield. As previously discussed, HPW is soluble in reaction medium, favoring higher initial reaction rate. For both catalysts, HMF yields were kept constant till 100 min. After this reaction time, a drop in HMF yield from 96 % to 83 % was observed for pure HPW; while HMF yield was increased from 80 % to 95 %, for HPW/AC. These changes in HMF yield are mainly related to the higher acidity of the pure HPW that favors parallel reactions consuming the formed HMF. Ravi et al. [80] prepared phosphate-functionalized porous organic polymers (POPs) as catalyst for fructose dehydration in DMSO and the best result was fructose conversion > 99 % and 78 % of HMF selectivity after 30 min at 160 °C. Authors attributed these good results to high surface area and mesopore volume, which enabled easier access of the reactant and intermediate molecules to the surface acid sites. 3.2.1 Effect of HPW/AC amount on the dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF In order to investigate the effect of the catalyst amount in fructose conversion and HMF yield, reactions were performed varying the catalyst concentration from 5 to 15 wt%. Other reaction parameters were kept unchanged; results are depicted in Fig. 11 . It is possible to observe that catalyst amount, in the evaluated range, presented little effect on fructose conversion, since after 30 min almost 100 % of fructose was converted for all the catalyst amounts tested. The same trend was observed in our previous work using HPW/MCM-41 as catalyst [9]. However, at 100 °C, a small advantage can be observed for this solid over HPW/AC, which can be related to its greater acidity. Yang et al. [79] also reported the same trend of the fructose conversion for different amount of phosphoric carbon as catalyst using water:2-butanol as solvent at 160 °C. Qu et al. [81], using a heteropolyacid ([MIMPS]3PW12O40) catalyst and DMSO, obtained different results. They tested different fructose:catalyst ratios, from 1:1 to 4:1, and the best result was obtained with 2:1 (0.5 g of fructose and 0.25 g of catalyst). Zhao et al. [74], using a sulfonated carbon as catalyst, observed that the conversion gradually increases from 86.5 % to 100 % as the catalyst:fructose ratio increases from 5 % to 40 %, while HMF yield first increases from 60.7 % (5 %) to 75.4 % (20 %), followed by a slight decrease to 70.8 % (40 %). When the catalyst concentration was 5 wt%, the fructose conversion was 100 % with HMF yield of 64 % in 40 min. Increasing catalyst concentration to 10 wt%, HMF yield increased to 85 % in 20 min. With an additional increase in the catalyst amount to 15 wt%, HMF conversion remained unchanged, while the HMF yield was decreased marginally at reaction times above 80 min. This yield decrease may be attributed to the presence of higher density of active acid sites in the reaction media, favoring side reactions that convert the produced HMF to organic acids, soluble polymers and humins [70,78,82]. Bhanja et al. [83], using a Cl functionalized SBA-15 as catalyst and DMSO, varied catalyst amount from 0 to 25 mg, and observed that the maximum yield (74 mol %) was obtained with 25 mg of catalyst; further increase in catalyst amount did not affect yield significantly. Hu et al. [84] observed a similar behavior, where an excess of catalyst in the reaction media could accelerate HMF decomposition. 3.2.2 Effect of temperature on the dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF The influence of the reaction temperature towards fructose dehydration to HMF over HPW/AC catalyst was studied in the temperature range from 100 to 140 °C (Fig. 12 ). It is possible to observe that reaction temperature showed great influence on the HMF synthesis. Fructose conversion gradually increased during the reaction for the three testing temperatures. It may be noted that fructose conversion was 37 % in 20 min at 100 °C, while it was 97 % at 120 °C and total fructose conversion was reached at 140 °C for the same reaction time. It is worth mentioning that it took 100 min to achieve total fructose conversion at 100 °C. These results reveal that high temperatures favor acid-catalyzed dehydration of fructose to HMF. Fructose dehydration to produce HMF is temperature sensitive and it significantly increases reaction rate due to the endothermic nature of the fructose dehydration reaction [85]. Depending on the system components, some authors reported that temperature increase favors fructose conversion at relatively low temperatures (< 140 °C); otherwise, temperatures higher than 140 °C do not have a pronounced effect on the fructose conversion and could accelerate HMF decomposition [59]. The temperature increase resulted in remarkable increase in HMF yield. For instance, HMF yield of 11 % was obtained after 30 min at 100 °C. With temperature increase to 120 and 140 °C, HMF yields reached 82 and 100 % at the same reaction time. HMF yield may be considered stable at 120 and 140 °C after 20 min; for reaction at 100 °C this stability is reached after 80 min. It strongly indicates that at low temperatures the produced HMF is consumed to produce humins. It is important to point out that humins are compounds difficult to quantify [10,75] but they are easy to identify, since the color of the reaction solution changes from yellow to brown. This formation of humins at low temperatures might be related to favoring dehydration of fructose to HMF at higher reaction temperature, reducing fructose polymerization. On the other hand, some works in literature report that the activation energy for HMF degradation is favored by temperature increase [86]. Literature, in general, present some different results regarding the HMF yield with temperature increase, with HMF yield first increasing and then decreasing with the progress of the reaction at different temperatures. This will be explored in kinetics analysis, where the value of rate constant of fructose dehydration (K) indicates the slow kinetics of fructose conversion at low temperatures. Guo et al. [87] promoted fructose dehydration to HMF using a sulfonated SBA-15 and tested different temperatures (90, 100, 120 and 140 °C) in 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride. Authors observed that HMF yield increased almost linearly with reaction temperature, reaching an optimum of 81 %, at 120 °C; an additional increase in temperature up to 140 °C induces a slight HMF yield decrease after 1 h. Yang et al. [88] reported a significant drop of HMF yield after 2 h of reaction, independent of temperature. They used a biphasic DMSO/water system and functionalized silica nanoparticles as catalyst. Li et al. [89] reported similar results for HMF yield profiles with increasing temperature. They used an ionic liquid 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride ([BMIM][Cl]) in presence of carbonaceous microspheres as catalyst at 70, 80 and 90 °C. The HMF yield increased to a maximum of 80.7 % in 60 min when temperature was 70 °C, and then reached a plateau. When the reaction temperature was increased to 80 or 90 °C, the reaction rate increased in the initial stages of the reaction. The reaction performed at 90 °C tends to stabilize after 40 min; in another hand, at 80 °C, HMF yield dropped after 40 min. Tacacima et al. [85] produced HMF from catalytic fructose dehydration under Purolite® SGC650H, a gel-type strongly acidic resin, applied as a catalyst, using DMSO. All experiments were carried out in a batch reactor and in a continuous packed bed reactor. Authors stated that the reactor performance showed the higher the temperature the higher HMF yield; they related this temperature rise effect to the higher activation energy of the HMF formation than the HMF consumption. Table 3 shows a comparison between the results obtained in this work and some results from the literature for fructose dehydration to HMF. For the sake of comparison, reactions using other solvents than DMSO were also presented. Our best result was at 140 °C for 30 min, reaching 99.3 % of HMF yield. Other HPAs with lower total acidity, such as HSiW [29] and H8PV5Mo7O40 [90], required longer reaction times to achieve high yields of HMF. Qu et al. [81] obtained 99.1 % of HMF yield after 120 min and using sec-butanol as solvent, in an homogeneous reaction media. In our previous work [9], using HPW/MCM-41 as catalyst, 80 % of HMF yield was reached after 60 min at 120 °C. In the same line, Lv et al. [29], using an HPW supported on SiO2, obtained just 71 % of HMF yield after 150 min at 170 °C in a mixture of solvents. In addition, the exchange of HPW protons by other cations, such as Cs+ [9] and [MIMPS]+ [81], did not reduce reaction time needed to reach high HMF yields. Using a phosphoric carbon, the best result obtained by Yang et al. [79] was 93.7 % of HMF yield using DMSO as solvent, at 160 °C for 180 min. In another work using modified activated carbon as catalyst and DMSO, Zhao et al. [74] obtained an HMF yield of 90 %; nevertheless, the reaction lasted 90 min and was performed at 160 °C. Moreover, in a previous work of our research group [91], we reported that fructose dehydration reaction in DMSO was more selective to HMF production over aqueous and biphasic system. 3.2.3 Reusability of HPW/AC catalyst The reusability of a heterogenous catalyst is an important property, since it evaluates the stability of the catalyst, its economic viability and environmental friendliness for practical applications. The dehydration of fructose to HMF was carried out in 5 cycles at 140 °C for 30 min. As shown in Fig. 13 , it was observed that the catalyst was stable for five times without significant loss of its catalytic activity; the conversion decreased from 100 to 98 % and HMF yield from 99.3–87.8 %. These results indicated that the HPW supported on AC was stable during the reaction process. The catalyst maintained its oxidation state (typical of the Keggin structure), as can be seen in XPS spectra of the catalyst after recycling (Fig. S5). There was a slight drop in HMF yield after the third recycling reaction, which is probably related to the HPW leaching, as shown by EDS analysis (Table S1) of the reused catalyst (HPW load in AC decreased from 51 % to 41 %). It is probably caused by the washing process of the catalyst between the reaction cycles, once HPW is highly water soluble. 3.2.4 Kinetics analysis Based on the experimental results of fructose dehydration to HMF in DMSO, using HPW/AC as a catalyst, we looked for a kinetic model that could represent the reaction rate. For this, the dehydration reaction was considered as a first order reaction and, thus, it was possible to estimate the kinetic parameters of this batch process. According to the literature, fructose dehydration to HMF can be modeled as an irreversible first order reaction, since the determining step for this reaction is the fructose dehydration to the corresponding enol and the reverse reaction (enol to fructose) is thermodynamically unlikely [6,92,93]. In addition, based on different works in the literature [9,26,85], it is possible to simplify the reaction scheme previously proposed (Fig. 1), as fructose dehydration in DMSO significantly reduces the number of side reactions (polymerization of fructose or HMF and rehydration of HMF to organic acids) and the HMF yield rises during the reaction. That way, the stoichiometric of the reaction could be expressed as follows: C6H12O6 → C6H6O3 + 3H2O The overall fructose dehydration to HMF was represented by a simple power-law model/Arrhenius equation for kinetic analysis. The reaction rate for this reaction was given as follows: r = d C F r u c t o s e d t = - k ∙ C F r u c t o s e ∴ k = k 0 e - E a R T where, r is the rate of fructose conversion (mol L−1 min−1), k is the rate constant from fructose to HMF (min−1), Cfructose is the fructose concentration (mol L−1), ko is the pre-exponential factor, Ea is the activation energy (kJ. mol−1), T is the reaction temperature (K) and R is the universal gas constant. The rate constants of fructose conversion to HMF were obtained by plotting ln(1 - XF) vs. reaction time (t) at different temperatures. The first-order reaction model fitted well with the experimental data, achieving rate constants of 0.0297 (R2 = 0.997), 0.111(R2 = 0.999) and 0.853 min−1 (R2 = 0.994) at 100, 120 and 140 °C, respectively. The natural logarithmic values of rate constants of fructose dehydration vs. (1/T) (Arrhenius graphs) were plotted as shown in Fig. 14 . As shown in this figure, kinetic analysis of fructose dehydration is a first-order process, since the experimental data show a large positive linear correlation (R2 = 0.981), which is in good agreement with literature [6,9]. In addition, the value of k increased when increasing the reaction temperature, indicating that a higher reaction temperature is favorable for the HMF synthesis. The activation energy calculated from the slope is 109.4 kJ mol−1. The average value of activation energies for HMF synthesis from fructose in non-aqueous systems (e. g. mixed solvents, biphasic systems and ionic liquid) presented by Van Putten et al. [6] was ∼108 kJ. mol−1. For these authors, different catalytic systems behave differently, making it impossible to draw general conclusions. It is possible to observe that the activation energy of fructose dehydration in this work is in the same order of magnitude. However, we can observe a reduction when comparing with the activation energy reported by Zhang et al. [94] that used maleic acid and AlCl3 self-assemble as catalytic complexes (Al–(MA)2–(OH)2(aq)) for aqueous systems: about 128–158 kJ mol−1. In comparison with our previous work [9], whose reaction conditions are the same, the activation energy calculated for fructose dehydration was 58.7 kJ mol−1 for HPW/MCM-41, the use of HPW/AC did not present a significant reduction in activation energy; however, this solid showed higher HMF yield, as previously mentioned. This result again supports the advantages of the HMF/AC system for dehydration of the fructose. 4 Conclusions The dehydration of fructose to HMF was evaluated over HPW supported on activated carbon. It was found that conversion and HMF yield were mostly dependent on the reaction temperature. It should be noted that reaction time and catalyst amount have affected mainly HMF yield. The highest HMF yield was obtained with HPW/AC (99.3 %) with a catalyst loading of 10 wt% at 140 °C after 30 min. Overall, HPW/AC is a promising catalyst for the acid-catalyzed conversion of fructose into value-added chemicals, like HMF, in combination with DMSO as solvent. Besides, anchoring HPW in the high specific area activated carbon promoted the heterogenization and thermal stabilization of this strong acidic active phase. The catalyst presents low cost, easy and fast preparation. Additionally, this catalyst proved to be stable in five cycles of reuse, with only small decrease in HMF yield due to leaching of HPW. A kinetic model for fructose dehydration with the present catalyst was derived, with first-order reaction model fitting well the experimental data, and the activation energy was 109.4 kJ mol−1. coredata.dc:description: Phophotungstic acid (HPW) supported on activated carbon (AC) was prepared and used for dehydration of fructose to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), a biomass-derived precursor for chemicals and fuels. Different characterization techniques showed that Keggin structure of HPW was maintained after impregnation process by incipient wetness method with ethanol as solvent. The high mass content of the active phase (50 wt%) on the support resulted in accessible acid sites and high acid density, important for the dehydration reaction. The effects of reaction time, catalyst amount, and temperature were investigated. The catalytic system with dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) as solvent provided an efficient transformation of fructose to HMF, resulting in high HMF yields (99.3 %) and total fructose conversion after 30 min of reaction at 140 °C. Fructose conversion was not significantly affected by the catalyst amount. On the other hand, the increase in temperature resulted in greater and faster conversion. HMF yield was deeply affected by all reaction variables. Moreover, HPW/AC was reused five times without significant loss of activity. Additionally, a kinetic evaluation was performed and the activation energy of fructose conversion to HMF was 109.4 kJmol−1.
coredata.dc:title: Phosphotungstic acid on activated carbon: A remarkable catalyst for 5-hydroxymethylfurfural production
